definitions.definition: to create a threat, problem, etc. that has to be dealt with

examples.text: Obesity poses real risks to health and happiness.
Pollutants in the river pose a real risk to the fish.
the dangers posed by the possession of nuclear weapons
the environmental threat posed by oil spillages

definitions.definition: to ask a question, especially one that needs serious thought

examples.text: The new play poses some challenging questions.

definitions.definition: to sit or stand in a particular position in order to be painted, drawn or photographed

examples.text: The delegates posed for a group photograph.
They posed briefly for pictures before driving off.
They were only too delighted to pose for the cameras.
He was persuaded to pose for his portrait.

definitions.definition: to pretend to be somebody in order to trick other people

examples.text: The gang entered the building posing as workmen.

definitions.definition: to dress or behave in a way that is intended to impress other people

examples.text: I saw him out posing in his new sports car.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French poser (verb), from late Latin pausare ‘to pause’, which replaced Latin ponere ‘to place’. The noun dates from the early 19th cent.
